newsitem.title: USA: Calif says $500 mln bonds to fund capital projects.
newsitem.headline: Calif says $500 mln bonds to fund capital projects.

text.p: California state Treasurer Matt Fong said Tuesday the state sold $500 million in new money and refunding general obligation bonds to fund a variety of capital projects.
Of the $500 million, $129 million was new money while $371 million would refund outstanding commercial paper notes.

Fong said the proceeds of the various purpose general obligation bonds would finance a variety of capital projects, including improvement of rail transportation, water reclamation, county correctional and juvenile facilities, and higher education and other school facilities.

The sale received bids from Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch & Co. The bonds were awarded to Lehman Brothers with a lower true interest cost of 5.5094 percent. Merrill Lynch's bid was 5.5113 percent.
"These bonds will fund some of the most essential functions of government," Fong said.
The bonds will be sold in $5,000 denominations, with maturities ranging from 1997 to 2026. Bonds maturing on or after June 1, 2008 are subject to optional redemption prior to maturity, Fong said.
